elements.content: Five d10 transition-metal clusters, {[Zn15(2,6-Hbptp)­(2,6-bptp)7­(μ2-O)4­(μ2-OH)4­(HCOO)2­(NO3)­(H2O)2]·​20H2O} (1), {[Zn8(2,6-Hbptp)­(2,6-bptp)5­(μ3-O)2]·​(ClO4)·​7H2O} (2), {[Cd8(2,6-Hbptp)2­(2,6-bptp)4­(μ3-O)2]·​(NO3)2·​10H2O} (3), {[Ag7(2,6-Hbptp)­(2,6-bptp)3]·​4H2O·​CH3OH} n (4), and {[Ag6(2,6-Hbptp)2­(2,6-bptp)2]­[Ag6(2,6-Hbptp)2­(2,6-bptp)2]2·​30H2O·​4CH3OH} (5), based on bent ligand 2,6-bis­[3-(pyrazin-2-yl)-1,2,4-triazolyl]­pyridine (2,6-H2bptp) have been synthesized. Compound 1 exhibits a novel fanlike Zn15 cluster, which is the highest-nuclearity Zn cluster with 2,6-H2bptp reported thus far. In 2 or 3 (M = Zn/Cd), each ligand coordinates to three M2+ ions, to form an M8L6 cluster. The structure of compound 4 is a Ag6 cluster-based 1D chain, where each hexanuclear [Ag6(2,6-Hbptp)­(2,6-bptp)3]− cluster links its equivalent ones via sharing the Ag atom. Compound 5 contains two kinds of Ag6 clusters, and the alternating arrangement of them gives the final structure. It is worth mentioning that the Ag–Ag bond distances in 4 and 5 are relatively very short and suggest a closed-shell d10–d10 argentophilic interaction. The luminescence properties of compounds 1–5 have been researched at ambient and low temperatures. Interestingly, the emission intensities of 1–5 increase gradually upon cooling. A new strong emission band for 4 appears at 610 nm exhibiting red-orange luminescence. The low-energy emissions (620 nm) of 5 gradually blue shift to shorter wavelengths.

elements.content: Five metal clusters have been successfully synthesized by reaction of bent ligand 2,6-bis­[3-(pyrazin-2-yl)-1,2,4-triazolyl]­pyridine (2,6-H2bptp) together with Zn­(II)/Cd­(II)/Ag­(I) salts. The photoluminescent properties of as-synthesized compounds were investigated between 298 and 10 K to track their response to temperature.

elements.content: The recent upsurge in the interest in designing and fabricating polynuclear clusters of 3d metal ions has been strongly encouraged by their attractive structures and versatile applications. Up to now, various polynuclear clusters with fascinating architectures and functional properties have been designed and assembled by the careful selection of basic components, such as the structure of chelating ligands, metal centers, anions, and solvents. Among the reported polynuclear transition-metal clusters, two outstanding strategies have been developed for the self-assembly of molecular structures. One is that the O2–, OH–, and halogen ions employed may play pivotal roles in the process of metal clusters in μ2, μ3, or μ4 bridging modes. The other one is the combination of polydentate ligands with metal ions for building up clusters, which have drawn a lot of attention in the area of supramolecular chemistry recently.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The recent upsurge in the interest in designing and fabricating polynuclear clusters of 3d metal ions has been strongly encouraged by their attractive structures and versatile applications. Up to now, various polynuclear clusters with fascinating architectures and functional properties have been designed and assembled by the careful selection of basic components, such as the structure of chelating ligands, metal centers, anions, and solvents. Among the reported polynuclear transition-metal clusters, two outstanding strategies have been developed for the self-assembly of molecular structures. One is that the O2-, OH-, and halogen ions employed may play pivotal roles in the process of metal clusters in μ2, μ3, or μ4 bridging modes. The other one is the combination of polydentate ligands with metal ions for building up clusters, which have drawn a lot of attention in the area of supramolecular chemistry recently.

elements.content: Among the various multidentate ligands, N-containing ligands, such as pyridine, triazole, tetrazole, and their derivatives, are frequently used to construct the desirable products. To continue our in-depth study on triazole–pyrazine systems, we have turned to the 2,6-bis­[3-(pyrazin-2-yl)-1,2,4-triazolyl]­pyridine (2,6-H2bptp). As we know, some coordination polymers based on triazole–pyridine ligands such as 3,5-bis­[3-(pyrid-2-yl)-1,2,4-triazolyl]­pyridine and 2,6-bis­[3-(pyrid-3-yl)-1,2,4-triazolyl]­pyridine are reported currently. However, the coordination chemistry based on 2,6-H2bptp (Scheme ), where the terminal pyridine moieties are replaced by the two pyrazine groups, has attracted little attention. To our knowledge, only Hou’s group discovered the conversion from a [2 + 2] nest double-helical column to a cationic spiral staircase through liquid anion stimulations. Furthermore, high-nuclearity metal clusters built from 2,6-H2bptp are never reported, which is still a great challenge. Therefore, it is necessary to further explore the synthetic strategy and chemical properties of the high nuclear clusters based on 2,6-H2bptp. It as a good bridging/chelating ligand containing 11 potential N-donors, which can serve as a unidentate, bidentate, or multidentate connector to construct diverse metallosupramolecular systems. Moreover, 2,6-H2bptp has five aromatic rings, which may show diverse coordination modes and conformations, thus making it easier to form an intriguing structure of high nuclearity than to form single metal-ion precursors.

elements.content: In this work, we obtain a series of d10 metal clusters stabilized by 2,6-H2bptp. They are formulated as {[Zn15(2,6-Hbptp)­(2,6-bptp)7­(μ2-O)4(μ2-OH)4­(HCOO)2­(NO3)­(H2O)2]·​20H2O} (1), {[Zn8(2,6-Hbptp)­(2,6-bptp)5­(μ3-O)2]·​(ClO4)·​7H2O} (2), {[Cd8(2,6-Hbptp)2­(2,6-bptp)4­(μ3-O)2]·​(NO3)2·​10H2O} (3), {[Ag7(2,6-Hbptp)­(2,6-bptp)3]·​4H2O·​CH3OH} n (4), and {[Ag6(2,6-Hbptp)2­(2,6-bptp)2]­[Ag6(2,6-Hbptp)2­(2,6-bptp)2]2·​30H2O·​4CH3OH} (5). To explore luminescence thermochromic phenomena, the photoluminescent properties of the five fascinating polynuclear clusters are investigated between 298 and 10 K to track their response to temperature. In addition, the coordination modes of the 2,6-H2bptp ligand have been discussed in detail.

elements.content: The 2,6-H2bptp ligand was bought commercially. Elemental analyses of C, H, and N were conducted on an Elementar Vario microanalyzer. Powder Xray diffraction (PXRD) was performed on a Cu Kα radiation equipped RIGAKU DMAX 2500 diffractometer. Thermogravimetric spectrometric analysis (TGA) was carried out on preweighed samples using a NETZSCH STA 449C instrument during 30–1000 °C. Infrared (IR) spectra were recorded with KBr pellets on a PerkinElmer Spectrum One FTIR spectrometer in the range of 400–4000 cm–1. Luminescent spectra of the clusters were recorded on an FLS920 with 450 W xenon light.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

The 2,6-H2bptp ligand was bought commercially. Elemental analyses of C, H, and N were conducted on an Elementar Vario microanalyzer. Powder Xray diffraction (PXRD) was performed on a Cu Kα radiation equipped RIGAKU DMAX 2500 diffractometer. Thermogravimetric spectrometric analysis (TGA) was carried out on preweighed samples using a NETZSCH STA 449C instrument during 30-1000 °C. Infrared (IR) spectra were recorded with KBr pellets on a PerkinElmer Spectrum One FTIR spectrometer in the range of 400-4000 cm-1. Luminescent spectra of the clusters were recorded on an FLS920 with 450 W xenon light.

elements.content: Zn­(NO3)2·​6H2O (60 mg, 0.20 mmol), 2,6-H2bptp (37 mg, 0.10 mmol), and a mixed solvent (8 mL, DMF/H2O =1:1, DMF = N,N-dimethyl­formamide) were sealed in a vessel and heated at 120 °C. After 3 days, yellow crystals were formed when the vessel was cooled to 30 °C (Yield: 79% based on ligand). Anal. Calcd for C138H123­N89O37Zn15 (fw 4601.17): C, 36.02%; H, 2.70%; N, 27.09%. Found: C, 36.07%; H, 2.81%; N, 27.26%. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3406­(m), 1622­(m), 1583(s), 1498­(w), 1380(s), 1145­(w), 1068­(m), 812­(w), 746­(w).

elements.content: Diffraction data for compounds 1–5 were collected on a SuperNova at 100 K. The structures were solved using direct methods and refined on F 2 using SHELXTL. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters. Hydrogen atoms from aromatic carbon atoms were generated geometrically, while those on the water molecules could not be determined. PLATON/SQUEEZE were used in compounds 1–4, due to the disordered solvent molecules, which could not be modeled properly. The final chemical formulas of 1–4 were calculated from SQUEEZE results combined with the TGA and elemental analyses data. The CCDC numbers are , , , , and for 1–5, respectively. The information of compounds 1–5 on crystallographic data and selected bond lengths and angles are summarized in Table and Table S1 ().
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure Determination

Diffraction data for compounds 1-5 were collected on a SuperNova at 100 K. The structures were solved using direct methods and refined on F 2 using SHELXTL. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters. Hydrogen atoms from aromatic carbon atoms were generated geometrically, while those on the water molecules could not be determined. PLATON/SQUEEZE were used in compounds 1-4, due to the disordered solvent molecules, which could not be modeled properly. The final chemical formulas of 1-4 were calculated from SQUEEZE results combined with the TGA and elemental analyses data. The CCDC numbers are , , , , and  for 1-5, respectively. The information of compounds 1-5 on crystallographic data and selected bond lengths and angles are summarized in Table  and Table S1 ().

Compound 1 crystallizes in monoclinic space group C2/c. There is an isolated fanlike Zn15 cluster in the structure of 1, which consisted of 15 Zn2+ ions, one 2,6-Hbptp– ligand, seven 2,6-bptp2– ligands, one NO3 – anion, two HCOO– anions, four OH– groups, four O2– anions, two coordinated water molecules, and 20 free water molecules (Figure a). Of the Zn2+ ions, the Zn3 atom is surrounded by three O atoms and one N atom, displaying a distorted tetrahedron geometry. Zn1, Zn2, Zn4, Zn5, Zn6, and Zn7 are all five-coordinated, resulting in a distorted square pyramid geometry (Figure c). Zn1, Zn4, Zn5, and Zn7 are in an N3O2 environment, while Zn2 and Zn6 lie in an N4O environment. Differing from Zn1 to Zn7, the Zn8 center (site occupancy factor (SOF) = 0.5) is best portrayed as a distorted {ZnN4O2} octahedral geometry. To our knowledge, compound 1 represents the highest-nuclearity Zn cluster with 2,6-H2bptp ligands reported thus far. With further insight into this cluster, the eight spacers are alternately located “above and below” the plane that is defined by the 15 Zn ions. The 15 Zn atoms are significantly formed in an attractive fanlike structure, and the distances of neighboring zinc atoms are 3.367(1)–4.987(2) Å.

Zn1, Zn2, Zn4, Zn5, Zn6, and Zn7 are all five-coordinated, resulting in a distorted square pyramid geometry (Figure c). Zn1, Zn4, Zn5, and Zn7 are in an N3O2 environment, while Zn2 and Zn6 lie in an N4O environment. Differing from Zn1 to Zn7, the Zn8 center (site occupancy factor (SOF) = 0.5) is best portrayed as a distorted {ZnN4O2} octahedral geometry. To our knowledge, compound 1 represents the highest-nuclearity Zn cluster with 2,6-H2bptp ligands reported thus far. With further insight into this cluster, the eight spacers are alternately located "above and below" the plane that is defined by the 15 Zn ions. The 15 Zn atoms are significantly formed in an attractive fanlike structure, and the distances of neighboring zinc atoms are 3.367(1)-4.987(2) Å.

elements.content: Compounds 2 and 3 are isostructural but contain different counteranions and solvents. Therefore, the cluster unit structure of 2 is taken as the example to be described in detail. Compound 2 crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅, and eight Zn2+ ions, one 2,6-Hbptp– ligand, five 2,6-bptp2– ligands, two O2– anions, one ClO4 – anion, and seven lattice water molecules exist in the asymmetric unit (Figure a). The Zn atoms are coordinated in two types of coordination geometries. Both Zn1 and Zn8 are five-coordinated with a distorted square pyramid geometry surrounded by five nitrogen atoms from N-donor ligands. Zn2 and Zn3 are in an N3O1 environment, resulting in a distorted tetrahedron geometry. For Zn4 to Zn7, they adopt a distorted square pyramid geometry, coordinated by four N atoms and one μ3-O atom. The Zn–O (1.944(5)–2.074(3) Å) and Zn–N (1.986(2)–2.403(5) Å) bond distances are comparable to the reported lengths. As shown in Figures b and , eight Zn atoms define a bicapped trigonal antiprism polyhedron, Zn2 to Zn7 and two μ3-O atoms form the antiprism, and the remnant Zn1 and Zn8 atoms lie up and down the triangle faces, respectively. Each ligand coordinates to three Zn2+ ions, to form an M8L6 cluster. With further insight into the Zn8 cluster, both of the O atoms locate in the center of the two distinct Zn3 triangles, exhibiting two [Zn3(μ3-O)]4+ triangle cores that are wrapped by terminal [Zn­(2,6-Hbptp)­(2,6-bptp)2]3– and [Zn­(2,6-bptp)3]4– units. The mean distance between adjacent zinc atoms of two [Zn3(μ3-O)]4+ triangle cores is 3.408 Å, and the mean distance of a vertex Zn atom and a Zn atom in the neighboring triangle is 4.346 Å. The ClO4 – counterion and free water molecules disperse among the Zn8L6 clusters to balance the charges and steady the structure.

elements.content: Compound 4 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/n, and the asymmetric unit comprised seven Ag+ ions, one 2,6-Hbptp– ligand, three 2,6-bptp2– ligands, four free water molecules, and one free MeOH molecule (Figure a). The seven Ag atoms show two types of coordination geometries. Ag1, Ag2, Ag4, Ag5, and Ag7 are three-coordinated by nitrogen atoms of ligands, giving similar distorted T-shaped geometries. Both Ag3 and Ag6 are surrounded by two nitrogen atoms of two independent triazolyl rings, and N–Ag–N angles are 168.69(2)–174.12(6)°, resulting in the linear geometry. Among the Ag–N bonds, the distances of Ag1–N21 (2.636(4) Å), Ag2–N17 (2.597(4) Å), Ag4–N12 (2.598(4) Å), Ag5–N28 (2.606(3) Å), and Ag7–N43 (2.524(4) Å) are long, relatively, which imply a weak interaction between them. Interestingly, the Ag1 to Ag6 atoms are linked together by backbones of the ligands and direct Ag–Ag bonds, displaying a fascinating Ag6L4 cluster. Within the Ag6 cluster, the neighboring Ag–Ag separation ranges from 2.911(4) to 2.951(4) Å, which is shorter than the van der Waals contact distance for two Ag atoms (3.40 Å). Each hexanuclear [Ag6(2,6-Hbptp)­(2,6-bptp)3]− cluster links its equivalent ones via sharing the Ag7 atom to produce a 1D Ag6 cluster-based chain extending along the b axis (Figure b), and the average distance between the Ag7 ion and a Ag ion in the adjacent [Ag6(2,6-Hbptp)­(2,6-bptp)3]− cluster is 6.264 Å (Ag6–Ag7 = 6.200(2) Å, Ag7–Ag3A = 6.327(4) Å). The adjacent chains stack to each other through π···π interactions between pyrazine groups (centroid–centroid distance is 4.028 Å), giving a 3D supramolecular framework (Figure ).

elements.content: Compound 5 crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group Ccca. There are two kinds of Ag6 clusters in the structure of 5, namely, Ag6 a and Ag6 b (Figure a). Looking into the Ag6 a cluster (contains Ag1, Ag2, and Ag3), each ligand connects three Ag atoms that are further linked together by direct Ag–Ag bonds. The Ag1–Ag2, Ag2–Ag3, and Ag2–Ag2C distances are 2.964(3), 2.975(4), and 3.019(4) Å, respectively. In the process of forming the Ag6 b cluster (contains Ag4 and Ag5), six Ag atoms are connected together by four ligands and Ag–Ag interactions. The distances of Ag4–Ag5 and Ag5–Ag5D are 3.008(3) and 2.990(2) Å, respectively, implying strong Ag–Ag interactions between them. The silver atoms have two kinds of coordination numbers (2 and 3), which result in two different coordination geometries. Ag1 to Ag4 atoms adopt a distorted T-shaped geometry, which are coordinated by three nitrogen donors of the ligands. While the Ag5 atom is quite linearly coordinated by two nitrogen atoms with an N27–Ag5–N27A angle of 169.94(5)°. The bond lengths of Ag1–N1C (2.540(3) Å), Ag2–N17 (2.639(8) Å), Ag3–N22C (2.557(9) Å), and Ag4–N24B (2.566(9) Å) are long, relatively, which imply a weak interaction between these Ag and N atoms. In addition, π···π interactions exist between the terminal pyrazine groups of Ag6 a and Ag6 b clusters and the centroid-to-centroid distance is 3.629 Å. The alternating arrangement of Ag6 a and Ag6 b clusters gives the final structure (Figure b).

elements.content: In compounds 1–5, 2,6-H2bptp adopts 11 types of different coordination modes and acts as a tetra-, penta-, hexa-, or heptadentate ligand (Scheme ), which is conducive to form polynuclear clusters. For compound 1, the ligands all bridge three metals in modes A, B, and C. In compound 2, all of the ligands combine with three metals and adopt the coordination modes B, C, D, and E. In compound 3, all ligands combine three metals and adopt the coordination mode A. However, in compound 4, the 2,6-Hbptp– ligand is tetradentate and adopts the coordination mode F. The three bptp2– ligands bridge three or four metals in modes G, H and I. In compound 5, the ligands display tridentate or tetradentate coordination in modes J and K. Interestingly, two terminal pyrazine groups either exhibit monodentate or are free in compounds 1–5. Beyond expectation, one 2,6-H2bptp containing 11 potential N-donors bridges four metals at most, which may be due to the steric effect. It is noteworthy that the five aromatic rings of 2,6-H2bptp are difficult to locate on the same plane. Thus, the terminal pyrazine groups are slightly twisted with respect to the pyridyl group to relieve the steric hindrance, and the average dihedral angles between pyrazine and pyridyl rings change from 1.951 to 44.312° in compounds 1–5.
elements.clean_text:
Coordination Modes of the 2,6-H2bptp

In compounds 1-5, 2,6-H2bptp adopts 11 types of different coordination modes and acts as a tetra-, penta-, hexa-, or heptadentate ligand (Scheme ), which is conducive to form polynuclear clusters. For compound 1, the ligands all bridge three metals in modes A, B, and C. In compound 2, all of the ligands combine with three metals and adopt the coordination modes B, C, D, and E. In compound 3, all ligands combine three metals and adopt the coordination mode A. However, in compound 4, the 2,6-Hbptp- ligand is tetradentate and adopts the coordination mode F. The three bptp2- ligands bridge three or four metals in modes G, H and I. In compound 5, the ligands display tridentate or tetradentate coordination in modes J and K. Interestingly, two terminal pyrazine groups either exhibit monodentate or are free in compounds 1-5. Beyond expectation, one 2,6-H2bptp containing 11 potential N-donors bridges four metals at most, which may be due to the steric effect. It is noteworthy that the five aromatic rings of 2,6-H2bptp are difficult to locate on the same plane. Thus, the terminal pyrazine groups are slightly twisted with respect to the pyridyl group to relieve the steric hindrance, and the average dihedral angles between pyrazine and pyridyl rings change from 1.951 to 44.312° in compounds 1-5.

elements.content: As presented above, the structures of five compounds are quite different. Compound 1 was synthesized in the mixed solvent (8 mL, DMF/H2O = 1:1, DMF = N,N-dimethyl­formamide). There are four μ2-O2–, four μ2-OH–, and two HCOO– ions in 1 bridging throughout the 15 metal centers to form an attractive fanlike structure. In the absence of DMF, compound 2 with an M8L6 cluster can be obtained, in which two μ3-O2– ions locate in the center of Zn3 triangles. Moreover, in the case of compounds 4 and 5, their different structures also reveal the key role of the solvents. Compound 4 displays a 1D chain, which was obtained in 8 mL of MeOH. When the solvent was replaced by 6 mL of MeOH and 2 mL of H2O, a new Ag cluster of 5 was achieved. From the comparison, anions and solvents can subtly affect the formation of polynuclear clusters.
elements.clean_text:
Structural Diversity

As presented above, the structures of five compounds are quite different. Compound 1 was synthesized in the mixed solvent (8 mL, DMF/H2O = 1:1, DMF = N,N-dimethylformamide). There are four μ2-O2-, four μ2-OH-, and two HCOO- ions in 1 bridging throughout the 15 metal centers to form an attractive fanlike structure. In the absence of DMF, compound 2 with an M8L6 cluster can be obtained, in which two μ3-O2- ions locate in the center of Zn3 triangles. Moreover, in the case of compounds 4 and 5, their different structures also reveal the key role of the solvents. Compound 4 displays a 1D chain, which was obtained in 8 mL of MeOH. When the solvent was replaced by 6 mL of MeOH and 2 mL of H2O, a new Ag cluster of 5 was achieved. From the comparison, anions and solvents can subtly affect the formation of polynuclear clusters.

elements.content: The phase purity of compounds 1–5 was confirmed by powder XRD, and all the peaks matched well with the simulated ones, indicating the purity of samples 1–5 (Figure S1, ). The thermogravimetric analyses for the five samples were carried out from 30 to 1000 °C. Compound 1 shows a weight loss of 8.39% from 30 to 160 °C (calcd 8.61%), matching with the loss of 22 water molecules (Figure S2, ). For compound 2, seven free water molecules lose from 30 to 101 °C (found: 4.23%; calcd: 4.22%). The anhydrous framework starts to collapse until 480 °C. In the case of compound 3, 10 free water molecules are gradually removed after heating to 105 °C (found. 5.36%; calcd 5.23%). Upon further heating, the compound begins to decompose. From 30 to 190 °C, compound 4 shows the removal of one MeOH molecule and four lattice water molecules (found. 4.53%; calcd 4.47%) and no marked weight loss until 400 °C when the remaining framework starts to collapse. Compound 5 exhibits the release of free MeOH and water molecules below 120 °C (found. 9.36%; calcd 9.52%), and the desolvated framework is found to be stable up to 400 °C.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Powder Diffraction and Thermal Stability Analyses

The phase purity of compounds 1-5 was confirmed by powder XRD, and all the peaks matched well with the simulated ones, indicating the purity of samples 1-5 (Figure S1, ). The thermogravimetric analyses for the five samples were carried out from 30 to 1000 °C. Compound 1 shows a weight loss of 8.39% from 30 to 160 °C (calcd 8.61%), matching with the loss of 22 water molecules (Figure S2, ). For compound 2, seven free water molecules lose from 30 to 101 °C (found: 4.23%; calcd: 4.22%). The anhydrous framework starts to collapse until 480 °C. In the case of compound 3, 10 free water molecules are gradually removed after heating to 105 °C (found. 5.36%; calcd 5.23%). Upon further heating, the compound begins to decompose. From 30 to 190 °C, compound 4 shows the removal of one MeOH molecule and four lattice water molecules (found. 4.53%; calcd 4.47%) and no marked weight loss until 400 °C when the remaining framework starts to collapse. Compound 5 exhibits the release of free MeOH and water molecules below 120 °C (found. 9.36%; calcd 9.52%), and the desolvated framework is found to be stable up to 400 °C.

elements.content: Luminescent compounds have received significant attention due to their various applications as photoactive materials. Taking the promising luminescence properties of d10 coordination polymers into account, the photophysics of compounds 1–5 has been explored at ambient and cryogenic temperatures. As depicted in Figure S3 (), the free ligand 2,6-H2bptp presents blue luminescence with emission maxima at 450 nm (λex = 350 nm), which could probably be attributed to the π*π transitions. At room temperature, the emission spectra are observed with a maximum at 498 nm for 1, 468 nm for 2, 455 nm for 3, 438 nm for 4, and 455 nm/620 nm for 5, respectively, under an excitation maximum at 350 nm (Figure and Figure S4, ). To explore luminescence thermochromic phenomena, the photoluminescent properties of as-synthesized compounds were investigated between 298 and 10 K to track their response to temperature. Upon cooling with liquid nitrogen, photoemission spectra of different temperatures show that maximum emission peaks for compounds 1 and 3 have no obvious shift, but the intensity increases gradually. At 10 K, the maximum emission peak for 2 blue shifts to 446 nm and relatively strengthens. Compared with the free 2,6-H2bptp ligand, the emissions of compounds 1–3 can probably be attributed to the intraligand (π–π*) charge transition. For compound 4, as the temperature decreases to 200 K, a new emission band is found at around 610 nm (low-energy emission (LE)). In addition, the LE band shows no further change except for an increase of intensity with further cooling. For compound 5, the high-energy emission (HE) has no obvious shift with the decrease of temperature. While the low-energy emission (LE) gradually shifts to 593 nm at 10 K, the intensity of this LE band relatively strengthens. Compared with the emission of the free 2,6-H2bptp ligand, the high-energy emission (438 nm for 4; 455 nm for 5) can probably be assigned to the intraligand (IL) ππ* transitions, and the low-energy emission (610 nm for 4; 620 nm for 5) has a tentatively metal-to-ligand charge-transfer (MLCT) and/or ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) character, mixed with a metal-centered (MC) transition, which are comparable to other Ag­(I) complexes reported. The further lifetime measurements for compounds 1–5 are also investigated, and detailed data are listed in Table S2 (). The emission decay curves can be well-fitted, which are shown in Figure S5 (). For compounds 4 and 5, the lifetime at the low-energy band (microseconds) is longer than the high-energy band (nanoseconds), which may be due to the different charge migrations of LE and HE emissions. In addition, the slight increase of lifetime upon cooling may be caused by the reduction of the nonradiative decay.

elements.content: In this study, by using a V-shaped rigid ligand 2,6-H2bptp, we have successfully synthesized five fascinating polynuclear clusters under solvothermal conditions. The results illustrate that 2,6-H2bptp, which displays 11 types of coordination modes in compounds 1–5, can act as a versatile multidentate ligand. Compound 1 shows a fascinating fanlike Zn15 cluster, which is the highest-nuclearity Zn cluster based on 2,6-H2bptp reported up to now. Compounds 2 and 3 are isostructural, which all exhibit a distorted bicapped trigonal antiprism polyhedron. Compound 4 holds a Ag6 cluster-based 1D chain structure, while 5 contains two kinds of Ag6 clusters. In compounds 4 and 5, the Ag–Ag bond distances are relatively very short and imply strong metal–metal interactions between them. Furthermore, the solid-state photoluminescence properties of compounds 1–5 at ambient and cryogenic temperatures were investigated. The strong emission intensity makes these complexes potentially applicable in photochemistry, chemical sensors, and electroluminescent displays.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In this study, by using a V-shaped rigid ligand 2,6-H2bptp, we have successfully synthesized five fascinating polynuclear clusters under solvothermal conditions. The results illustrate that 2,6-H2bptp, which displays 11 types of coordination modes in compounds 1-5, can act as a versatile multidentate ligand. Compound 1 shows a fascinating fanlike Zn15 cluster, which is the highest-nuclearity Zn cluster based on 2,6-H2bptp reported up to now. Compounds 2 and 3 are isostructural, which all exhibit a distorted bicapped trigonal antiprism polyhedron. Compound 4 holds a Ag6 cluster-based 1D chain structure, while 5 contains two kinds of Ag6 clusters. In compounds 4 and 5, the Ag-Ag bond distances are relatively very short and imply strong metal-metal interactions between them. Furthermore, the solid-state photoluminescence properties of compounds 1-5 at ambient and cryogenic temperatures were investigated. The strong emission intensity makes these complexes potentially applicable in photochemistry, chemical sensors, and electroluminescent displays.

Zn­(NO3)2·​6H2O (60 mg, 0.20 mmol), 2,6-H2bptp (37 mg, 0.10 mmol), and a mixed solvent (8 mL, DMF/H2O =1:1, DMF = N,N-dimethyl­formamide) were sealed in a vessel and heated at 120 °C. After 3 days, yellow crystals were formed when the vessel was cooled to 30 °C (Yield: 79% based on ligand). Anal. Calcd for C138H123­N89O37Zn15 (fw 4601.17): C, 36.02%; H, 2.70%; N, 27.09%. cln_elements.content:
The phase purity of compounds 1–5 was confirmed by powder XRD, and all the peaks matched well with the simulated ones, indicating the purity of samples 1–5 (Figure S1, ). The thermogravimetric analyses for the five samples were carried out from 30 to 1000 °C. Compound 1 shows a weight loss of 8.39% from 30 to 160 °C (calcd 8.61%), matching with the loss of 22 water molecules (Figure S2, ). For compound 2, seven free water molecules lose from 30 to 101 °C (found: 4.23%; calcd: 4.22%). The anhydrous framework starts to collapse until 480 °C. In the case of compound 3, 10 free water molecules are gradually removed after heating to 105 °C (found. 5.36%; calcd 5.23%). Upon further heating, the compound begins to decompose. From 30 to 190 °C, compound 4 shows the removal of one MeOH molecule and four lattice water molecules (found. 4.53%; calcd 4.47%) and no marked weight loss until 400 °C when the remaining framework starts to collapse. Compound 5 exhibits the release of free MeOH and water molecules below 120 °C (found. 9.36%; calcd 9.52%), and the desolvated framework is found to be stable up to 400 °C.

Luminescent Properties

Luminescent compounds have received significant attention due to their various applications as photoactive materials. Taking the promising luminescence properties of d10 coordination polymers into account, the photophysics of compounds 1–5 has been explored at ambient and cryogenic temperatures. As depicted in Figure S3 (), the free ligand 2,6-H2bptp presents blue luminescence with emission maxima at 450 nm (λex = 350 nm), which could probably be attributed to the π*π transitions. At room temperature, the emission spectra are observed with a maximum at 498 nm for 1, 468 nm for 2, 455 nm for 3, 438 nm for 4, and 455 nm/620 nm for 5, respectively, under an excitation maximum at 350 nm (Figure and Figure S4, ). To explore luminescence thermochromic phenomena, the photoluminescent properties of as-synthesized compounds were investigated between 298 and 10 K to track their response to temperature. Upon cooling with liquid nitrogen, photoemission spectra of different temperatures show that maximum emission peaks for compounds 1 and 3 have no obvious shift, but the intensity increases gradually. At 10 K, the maximum emission peak for 2 blue shifts to 446 nm and relatively strengthens. Compared with the free 2,6-H2bptp ligand, the emissions of compounds 1–3 can probably be attributed to the intraligand (π–π*) charge transition. For compound 4, as the temperature decreases to 200 K, a new emission band is found at around 610 nm (low-energy emission (LE)). In addition, the LE band shows no further change except for an increase of intensity with further cooling. For compound 5, the high-energy emission (HE) has no obvious shift with the decrease of temperature. While the low-energy emission (LE) gradually shifts to 593 nm at 10 K, the intensity of this LE band relatively strengthens. Compared with the emission of the free 2,6-H2bptp ligand, the high-energy emission (438 nm for 4; 455 nm for 5) can probably be assigned to the intraligand (IL) ππ* transitions, and the low-energy emission (610 nm for 4; 620 nm for 5) has a tentatively metal-to-ligand charge-transfer (MLCT) and/or ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) character, mixed with a metal-centered (MC) transition, which are comparable to other Ag­(I) complexes reported. The further lifetime measurements for compounds 1–5 are also investigated, and detailed data are listed in Table S2 (). The emission decay curves can be well-fitted, which are shown in Figure S5 (). For compounds 4 and 5, the lifetime at the low-energy band (microseconds) is longer than the high-energy band (nanoseconds), which may be due to the different charge migrations of LE and HE emissions. In addition, the slight increase of lifetime upon cooling may be caused by the reduction of the nonradiative decay.

metadata.title:
A Series of d10 Metal Clusters Constructed
by 2,6-Bis[3-(pyrazin-2-yl)-1,2,4-triazolyl]pyridine: Crystal Structures
and Unusual Luminescences
